Sampling with ISTP manually

Source: vignettes/Sampling-cross-manual.Rmd
Sampling-cross-manual.Rmd
library(pimbayes)
#> Loading required package: JuliaCall
#> Loading required package: rje
#> Loading required package: rjags
#> Loading required package: coda
#> Linked to JAGS 4.3.1
#> Loaded modules: basemod,bugs

If required functions and variable names are provided, sampling with the ISTP will be performed with a function istp.manual(). Let’s apply this function to the example. Please see Sampling-cross for the example specification. The required arguments are as follows.

  1. posterior_fun: A function generating samples from convenience posteriors, which is proportional to the multiplication of convenience priors and likelihoods.
posterior_fun<-function(N){
  eta<- rdirichlet(N,data+1)
  se <- rbeta(N,25,3)
  sp <- rbeta(N,30,1.5)
  phi_lambda_matrix = cbind(se,sp,eta[,1:3])
  colnames(phi_lambda_matrix) = c("se","sp", paste0("eta[",1:3,"]"))
  return(phi_lambda_matrix)
}
  1. h_inv: h−1(ϕ,λ)=θh^{-1}(\phi,\lambda) = \theta.
h_cross_inv <- function(phiLambda) {
  eta11 = phiLambda[3]
  eta12 = phiLambda[4]
  eta21 = phiLambda[5]
  se = phiLambda[1]
  sp = phiLambda[2]
  eta22 = 1 - eta11 - eta12 - eta21
  denom = se+sp-1
  pi11 = 1/denom*(sp*eta11 + (sp-1)*eta21)
  pi12 = 1/denom*(sp*eta12 + (sp-1)*eta22)
  pi21 = 1/denom*((se-1)*eta11 + se*eta21)
  return(c(se,sp,pi11,pi12,pi21))
}
  1. N: Sample size (output), desired size of Monte Carlo output.
  2. weight_fun: The function that calculates weight. It will take theta_matrix, a matrix of posterior samples of parameters in original parameterization, and deter, a vector of determinants.
valid_A <-function(theta){
  pi = theta[3:5]
  pi = c(pi,1-sum(pi))
  all(pi>=0 & pi <=1)
}
weight_fun<-function(theta_matrix, deter){
  apply(theta_matrix, 1,
        function(theta) ifelse(valid_A(theta),(theta[1]+theta[2]-1)^(-2),0))
}
  1. var_name: A vector of names of variables.
var_name = c("se","sp",paste0("pi","[",c(11,12,21),"]"))

When we run the code with above arguments, we observe the following outputs.

data(small_cross)
data = small_cross

results = istp.manual(posterior_fun, h_cross_inv, 15000, weight_fun, var_name)

results$ess
#> [1] 14428.16

head(results$samples)
#>             se        sp    pi[11]    pi[12]     pi[21]
#> [1,] 0.9346337 0.9491935 0.2073573 0.1961809 0.12887012
#> [2,] 0.9148658 0.9764178 0.1905230 0.3181121 0.18174362
#> [3,] 0.8525637 0.9811990 0.3351536 0.2054532 0.05537213
#> [4,] 0.9584293 0.8968924 0.1709046 0.3732488 0.06980274
#> [5,] 0.9270133 0.9611020 0.2129229 0.3192126 0.19197050
#> [6,] 0.9476010 0.9526025 0.1649901 0.4196374 0.17491736
